term.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a word or expression with a particular meaning, especially one that is used for a specific subject or type of language
term.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Journalists were told in no uncertain terms that they were not welcome.
‘Multimedia’ is the term for any technique combining sounds and images.
term.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a fixed period of time during which someone does something or something happens
term.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The mayor was coming to the end of his term in office.
The men each received a 30-year prison term.
The lease runs for a term of 99 years.
term.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: one of the periods of time that the school or university year is divided into. In Britain, there are usually three terms in a year.
term.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Teachers often feel overworked in term time (=during the term).
The exams are at the end of the summer term.
that all-important first day of term
term.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: the end of a particular period of time
term.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The agreement reaches its term next year.
a child born two months before full term (=of pregnancy)
We can prolong life beyond its natural term.
term.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: one of the numbers or signs used in a mathematical calculation
term.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 3: a word or expression with a particular meaning, especially one that is used for a specific subject or type of language
term.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: The site provides a glossary of legal terms.
‘Gender’ is a technical term in grammar.
‘The Old Bill’ is a slang term for the police.
‘Pinko’ is a derogatory term for someone with socialist ideas.
‘Geek’ is used as a term of abuse.
The pope condemned both Nazism and Communism in strong terms.
Friends and relatives speak of him in glowing terms.
Can you explain to me in layman’s terms how my computer works?
term.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 4: a fixed period of time during which someone does something or something happens
term.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: He faced a maximum prison term of 25 years.
The president is elected for a five-year term.
The contract was for a fixed term of five years.
The maximum term was life imprisonment.
The governor ends his term of office in September.
She was sentenced to a long term of imprisonment.
She served a term as chairwoman of the council.
term.translation[0].note_box[2].heading: – Meaning 5: one of the periods of time that the school or university year is divided into. In Britain, there are usually three terms in a year.
term.translation[0].note_box[2].sections: The beginning of term was only two days away.
We had a party at the end of term.
On the last day of term we went home early.
The school term was about to start.
Are you looking forward to the new term?
Mrs Collins will be leaving us at the end of the summer term.
Parents need permission to take their children on holiday during term time.
term.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to use a particular word or expression to name or describe something
term.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: This condition is sometimes termed RSI, or repetitive strain injury.
These developments are loosely termed ‘advanced manufacturing techniques’.
Roosevelt termed himself and his policies ‘liberal’.
term.translation[1].definitions[0].note_: Term is often used in the passive
term.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a word or expression that has a particular meaning, especially in a technical or scientific subject
term.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Multimedia is the industry term for any technique that uses computers to combine sound and images.
term.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: a change of a price or cost in real terms has been calculated to include the effects of other changes such as INFLATION (=price rises over time)
term.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Cocoa prices fell to their lowest in real terms for over 50 years.
term.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: one of the conditions of an agreement, contract, or other legal document
term.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Under the terms of the contract, the company was to deliver 1,000 megawatts of electricity to New York.
term.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: the conditions under which you agree to buy or sell something
term.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: You may be able to find another policy offering the same cover on more favourable terms (=more cheaply, with easier ways to pay etc).
term.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: having the same advantages, rights etc as anyone else
term.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: US companies want to be able to compete on equal terms with their overseas rivals.
term.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: the agreed limits of what an official committee or report has been asked to study
term.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: The matter of compensation is not within the committee’s terms of reference.
term.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: over a period of time from now until a long, short etc time into the future
term.translation[2].definitions[6].examp: The company’s prospects look good in the long term.
term.translation[2].definitions[7].defin: a period of time for which someone has an important job or position, or that a government has power
term.translation[2].definitions[7].examp: The chairman’s term is six years.
The President hopes to be elected to a second term of office.
term.translation[2].definitions[8].defin: the period of time that a legal right or agreement continues for
term.translation[2].definitions[8].examp: New legislation would lengthen the term of patent protection to 20 years.
Expenses are refundable over the term of the contract (=during the time that it continues).
term.translation[2].definitions[9].defin: the period of time before something has to be paid or repaid
term.translation[2].definitions[9].examp: We’re trying to extend the term on our mortgage.
a promissory note with a term of 6 months
term.translation[2].definitions[10].defi: the end of the period of a business agreement
term.translation[2].definitions[10].exam: The policy reaches its term next year.
term.translation[2].definitions[11].defi: the period of time that an insurance contract lasts for, especially when this is less than one year
term.translation[2].definitions[12].defi: one of the numbers or signs used in a mathematical calculation
term.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to use a particular word or expression to name or describe something
term.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: He discussed the formation of what he termed ‘strategic alliances’.
term.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: money that is put in a bank or a loan that is given for a particular length of time
term.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: US dollar term deposits can be an excellent investment choice for you.
Its credit line was converted to a term loan that matures Oct. 31.
